result_data.course_description: An introduction to the work of four leading Positive Psychology researchers. Students will explore the latest research in subjective well-being, Positive Psychology and the moral emotions, Positive Psychology and culture, and Positive Psychology and decision-making.
result_data.instructors: Edward Diener, Jonathan Haidt, Paul Rozin, Barry Schwartz
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in fall term

result_data.course_description: This course explores positive psychology at the middle and high school level, particularly the ways in which schools can promote well being, citizenship and a sense of fulfillment in young people. We will focus on the positive psychology outcomes introduced in previous courses including positive emotions, character strengths and virtures (such as social intelligence, optimism, kindness, teamwork, wisdom, and creativity), and meaning.
result_data.course_title: Positive Psychology in Middle School and High School
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: While mainstream psychology in the last 50 years has focused on how to repair the worst things in life, positive psychology focuses on how to enhance the best things. This course introduces students to the research, theory, and intellectual history of positive psychology--of a psychology of human flourishing. Martin Seligman has hypothesized that there are three paths to human fllourishing: the Pleasant Life, the Engaged Life, and the Meaningful Life. At the root of these approaches to happiness are, respectively, the positive emotions, the strenghts and virtues, and meaning and purpose.
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in fall term

result_data.course_description: This basic methodology course will teach means of valid and reliable assessments of healthy human processes of positive emotions, engagement, character strengths and meaning in life. The first half of the course will trace the contemporary development of evaluation and classification methods in positive psychology. Milestones and existing directtions, especially in the context of psychopathology will bhe identified. The relationship between research and evaluation, as well as identification of distinguishing and overlapping positive characteristics (character strenghts) will be highlighted.
result_data.course_title: Assessment and Classification in Positive Psychology
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in fall term
Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: Students will review the many positive interventions that have been proposed from the time of the Buddha until now that are alleged to increase well-being. This will require a brief survey of world religions, philosophy, psychology, and self-help literature to try to understand the nature of positive interventions and the range of those that have been proposed. The principles, tests, and interventions in positive psychology are being applied in a growing number of arenas, including: education, coaching, corporate and organizational leadership, health, sports, disabilities, and clinical psychology and psychiatry. Students will learn about this range of applications, selecting or creating interventions to carry out and assess in vivo. Rigorous methodologies, such as random assignment placebo controlled designs, that separate inert interventions from active ingredients will be emphasized. This will begin to prepare students for the major application within their specialty they will carry out in the second half of their Master' program.
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in fall term
Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: This course will focus on how positive psychology principles and interventions can be used in the practice of coaching to increase well being, life satisfaction and fulfillment. Students will explore the goals/objectives and "best practices" of coaching and will contrast them with the theory, goals/objectives and "best practices" of positive psychology. In particular, we will discuss how the core objective of positive psychology--building character strengths and virtures to promote pleasure, engagement, and meaning--reinforces and deepens the philosophy behind coaching.
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: This course will focus on how positive psychology principles and interventions can be used in clinical practice to ameliorate psychological disorders and to increase well being, life satisfaction and fulfillment. Students will explore the theory, goals/objectives and "best practices" of traditional psychotherapy (psychodynamic, humanistic, and cognitive-behavioral) and will contrast them with the theory, goals/objectives and "best practices"of positive psycholog.In particular, we willcontrast the disease model of traditional psychotheray with the core objective of positive psychology - building character strengh and virtures to promote pleasure, engagement, and meaning. Students will compare and contrast theories of change and growth across the psychotherapy modalities and will learn how to integrate positive psychology's emphasis on enhancing strengths with traditional psychotherapies' goal of correcting weakness.
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: Economic pressures have radically transformed the healthcare system. Hospitals, in which the majority of complex care is delivered, have become heated political arenas in which decisions are increasingly the result of internse negotiations for scarce resources, not what is best for patients. Offices and outpatient clinics suffer under the same pressures. With the government and insurance industry continuing to reward corner cutting as opposed to quality, the future of American healthcare looks grim.
result_data.course_title: Positive Psychology in the Health Professions
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: This course examines the definition, measurement, effects, and development of positive organizational dynamics. Special emphasis is given to the application of research in positive psychology and positive organizational scholarship to the leadership and management of organizations.
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered in spring term

result_data.course_description: In this course students will extend the horizon of knowledge about positive interventions. Beginning with the rich theoretical base of psychological research on positive affect, engagement, and meaning, and building on current research on how to raise these various components of the full life, students will focus on the creation and testing of new and more effective interventions. Students will explore single interventions that integrate cognitive, affective, and somatic components, and they will experiment with ways of clustering individual interventions together for greater cumulative effect. Also emphasized will be the importance of appropriate fit between the intervention, the individual, and the cultural context so that single or clustered interventions can be applied with maximal effectiveness.
result_data.terms_offered_description: Course usually offered summer term only

result_data.course_description: In this course students will extend the horizon of knowledge about positive interventions. Beginning with the rich theoretical base of psychological research on positive affect, engagement, and meaning, and building on current research on how to raise these various components of the full life, students will focus on the creation and testing of new and more effective interventions. Students will explore single interventions that integrate cognitive, affective, and somatic components, and they will experiment with ways of clustering individual interventions together for greater cumulative effect. Also emphasized will be the importance of appropriate fit between the intervention, the individual, and the cultural context so that single or clustered interventions can be applied with maximal effectiveness.
